Author: Wang, C.; Liang, W.
Title: Corporate political strategy and performance in China: The moderating effects of top management orientation and social capital
Journal: Energy Education Science and Technology Part A: Energy Science and Research
Custom1: This study combines resource-based view and institutional theory to clarify the relationship between corporate political strategy and performance in transition China. We analyze the hypothesis using a multiple regression analysis approach, and 198 Chinese private firms are selected as the samples. The results conclude that: (1) Corporate political strategy will significantly impact on firm performance; (2) Financial incentive strategy, information strategy, lobbying strategy and political support strategy will significantly impact on firm performance; (3) Top management orientation moderates the relationship between corporate political strategy and firm performance; (4) Social capital developed from government officials moderates the relationship between corporate political strategy and firm performance. We explore the implications of these results for future research and practicing managers.
